Body: For example, a friend of mine posted a picture of a book series on Facebook and the start of his caption was "Read all 13!" I initially interpretted this as an imperative sentence ([ɹid] all 13), but after reading the entire capture, I figured out that it was actually a declarative sentence about what he had done ([ɹɛd] all 13). Is there a term for this phenomenon? I dub it "homonym confusion" if it lacks a name!
Title: Is there a term for reading a homonym that means one thing but interpreting it as another?

LastEditedUser.AboutMe:
Travelling armchair linguist.

Never studied in an institution but read books and web with probably more breadth than depth.

Always on the road surviving in a strange foreign language, currently Mongolian and Mandarin Chinese.

And I collect dictionaries.

OwnerUser.AboutMe: I am currently a junior at Penn State pursuing a B.Phil. in Linguistics and a B.S. in Psychology with minors in Arabic and Statistics. I plan to graduate in 2015 to pursue a Ph.D. in linguistics.
